author: @jenkurtz412
text: This was really great, thank you. I am taking the Google course then will follow up with the IBM as well. Luckily, Coursera is such an economical solution to pick up new skills that bring relevant knowledge without the price tag of official college credits - which are just not always necessary depending on the roles and industries you work.  Additionally, I do think its great to think about the domain knowledge you can apply these new skills to - as opposed to expecting this cert to just get you a new job automatically. I think of the analyst as being a key storyteller in order to be impactful to executives and leaders making decisions. If you do not really understand the data you're attempting to speak to, you will never be seen as a credible advisor to any leadership.  You really need to be able to understand the data you're looking at, what you'd like to learn from it, what's in it for the leaders you're giving insight to.

author: @monicayes3033
text: I am basically already a data scientist without the title but trying to get into the tech world. I‚Äôm on course 6/8 and have mixed feelings about the certificate but overall think it was great and structured well.  Did I need the certificate? Not really, I already knew the technical skills the course offered so I‚Äôm not sure there is any benefit to me putting it on my resume.  Is it still worth taking? I think it is great for someone like me who has a degree that is science related but doesn‚Äôt have professional business experience. Like the guests mentioned it is heavy on the process and decision making. I learned a lot of buzz words and other information that will help me interview well and definitely helped me develop a solid resume.  Is this good for someone with no experience? Absolutely. As someone who already analyzes data and constantly creates methodology, I can say the structure of the course is really about getting you used to thinking analytically. It‚Äôs also a great intro to technical skills although these alone will not get you a job since it‚Äôs a little barebones.  Do I recommend the certificate? Yes but only if you have motivation. If you are serious about a career in data analytics this is a good precursor to your career you just have to want it and have patience. You aren‚Äôt going to want to hear this but this is likely a baby step to getting to that career. You have to continue to develop the technical skills, update your resume, and make a portfolio or git.

author: @ivanklful
text: Awesome video Luke! The first time that I see real and honest feedback of the course. I'm 47-year old master of mechanical engineering, with 18-year engineering career, and I'm pretty passionate about data analytics, data science, as well as machine learning. I'm about to switch career, and I completed entire Google Analytics Professional Certificate over the 4-month period from July to November 2021, this year. My impressions are that the course is worth of attending, and considering that I'm not 100% beginner the first three were not very useful for me, as well as spreadsheets taking into account that I'm quite experience Excel user but SQL, R-language and the capstone project were excellent. Also a minus about this entire course is I would like to see more practicing, an instructor to lead the students through entire process of data analysis by using at least couple of practical examples! Anyway definitively worth of attending and devoting time!

author: @ofeariyo8750
text: I think Wale's point about not getting hung up on the "data analyst" title is very important for people that complete the course, especially for people attempting a career transition. It can cause you to miss out on great jobs that you could be qualified for based on your past experience. The data analyst skillset is very transferable, so it is important to keep an open mind while you job hunt. I was able to combine my previous customer support experience with the skills I acquired from this course to land a community research manager position. It took me about a month to get my official offer, but this course opened up a whole new career path that I didn't even know was available to me. Once I'm more settled in my new job, I plan on taking the Google Project Management course next so that I can meet the requirements for the CAPM exam. As far as the job search resources, I found that networking in real life did way more for me than anything they provided. I was able to interview for the job before it even became publicly available due to my networking efforts, so that is definitely another thing I would keep in mind. Thanks for the great content!

author: @supernovak23
text: Hi Luke! Love the channel. I know this is a bit past the mark for this video, but wanted to throw my two cents in. I became a data analyst first, and am now in the process of rounding out the certs, degree, and general experience to build upon this career path I discovered and love! I am currently running through the Google Data Analytic certificate, and I agree a lot of the focus is ground level up, and some overlap on the basics that I already know. Having said that, it fills in a few knowledge gaps and makes that foundation even stronger. If someone in my situation has the time and ability to afford and take a cert like this, it gives a generally understood signal to employers or recruiters that those foundational ideas  (spreadsheets, basic data analytics and project management concepts) are a known skill. There are far worse "unnecessary" certs to have, especially considering the overall quality and name recognition of a Google cert.

author: @tianchu9133
text: Hey Luke, very grateful for the great discussion on this video! I have a three plus years of being a data analyst. The past a few jobs involved in product management, category management and business analysis in the retail industry (e-commerce). I taught myself in using Excel, Tableau, SQL and Python. How much I use each one of them is really depends on the stage of my study progress and the particular task I am working on. I am now in the 7-days free trial of the course of Google Data Analyst Professional Certificate. Still feel hesitate whether should I keep moving forward on this course. I feel it is more suitable for very starter in data analysis. How much do you recommend this course for people who has some experiences in DA like me. Thanks!

author: @anonyme103
text: I did the data analysis nanodegree on Udacity and currently doing the Google DA Certificate, the main difference is for sure python and more technical stuff. However, in the Google cert they cover more day-to-day job scenarios and push you to work on your soft skills which the first one is not great at. Although I have a computer science degree, it is still not easy to find a job where I currently reside (Germany), junior positions require some kind of expertise learned from internships.

author: @shivasuresh5957
text: Super brief summary:  Data Analysis process theory - strong Instructors enthusiasm and engagement - strong Technical coverage of SQL, Tableau, R - average/mediocre 150 employer job consortium - poor  If you are completely new to data analysis this course may be  good fit since it really presents the steps in the data analysis process thoroughly.  If you already have some exposure to SQL, Tableau, Python/R  this course  likely won't teach you anything new technically.  If you are drawn by the 150 employer job consortium in the U.S. then I would not recommend since Google has fallen short here since the job resources they provide to certificate holders contain very few entry level data analyst jobs.

author: @PradeepSinghRajputOfficial
text: Hey Luke,  Being a data analyst for the last 1.5 years, here are my thought on the video: - Pretty well-made video, that keeps people interested in what is coming next. - *R vs Python* : Agree, they should have chosen Python or provided an option to switch. - *Excel is less important* : Strongly disagree, I use Excel as much as SAS on a daily basis or more. - *Certification is useful for getting the Job* : No, but I would like to add it to my resume.  *EDIT* : 2.3 Years now.  Some Analysts do use R, and some say that it is really good for statistics and educational purposes. But I would still want Python to be included in courses/certifications for Data Analysts.

author: @arnoldkabuya5969
text: So in a nutshell, the certificate says you have the skills and the portfolio says you applied the skills on real projects. Meaning one cannot exist without the other and its advisable to even volunteer for lots of projects and add on skills. Thats what I understand

author: @allisterblue5523
text: When the guy said that they taught you something more important than the practical skills (coding, basic main procedures), I thought he was going to speak about mathematical rigor, then when he said soft skill, it killed meü§£.   More seriously, I guess this can be a decent base for an analyst, if you have experience you can find a job with no or few academic qualifications, though an analyst summurizes data and then does presentations on it, in my experience; so if you want to do it, more power to you, just make sure you're not getting the wrong idea.  If you like the implementation and/or system architecture (databases, implementation, parallelization, decentrallization,etc), you should still go study CS.  If you like develloping new models to solve new issues, manage the risk of the model, boost performance, etc, you should study math and statistics, maybe with extra focus on the algorithmic side.

author: @GG-is1gk
text: Amazing content! Thank you for your effort! This was really helpful!

author: @bnbbattlesbraincancer
text: I‚Äôve ten years experience in data analytics but no relevant training so am half way through this cert now. So far it‚Äôs been very basic and process focused which to me seems correct. It should round out my experience nicely to have this so I‚Äôll be completing it.

author: @seekerj1643
text: Great follow up video after posting your initial video on the certificate. I think the expectation by many was that this certificate would instantly land them a job, or it would be as if Google would have facilitated their consortium of companies to reach out to every course completer, which is not the case. Overall, it was a very clean presentation of material which other providers have delivered in a very mundane way but it wasn't about job placement and in my opinion, I think that the majority of people that have completed the program won't mind that. However, some may have thought otherwise. I say take this program with a grain of salt as I had and think of it as a simple grouping of some data analysis concepts. Therefore, it doesn't matter whether they taught in R vs. Python. Go out now and learn how to clean, process, analyze, and visualize in Python if you like. Build a portfolio. Update your resume. Job search. I think with or without Google we all have to do our own home work.

author: @madhugarg7499
text: Will this Certification help to switch career into Data Science for an experienced person ?

author: @davidjr9389
text: Just completed the course 2 weeks ago, I did the course with the video at 1.25 speed as someone suggested, cause it's very slow at times, Like everyone has pointed out the beginning 3 modules of the course is kinda meh, it could have optional or at the end.   cons: 1. This certificate alone won't help you land a job, it doesn't get you prepared for the on-job scenarios, cause it is very theory intensive at times 2. Could have focused more on practical uses and more exercises or challenges using your skills throughout  pros: 1. It's worth doing it and getting a start in the data field  suggestion: Would be if the course started as you being hired as a data analyst at Google and you get tasks and more on the job scenario of what a data analyst would do, learn as you go and solve the tasks kinda way, they had a few exercises like that, but, maybe the whole course should be insightful and learning and more doing experience of an actual data analyst at Google. and how they did the same tasks/exercises and their thought process, rather than people from google just endlessly taking. LESS TALK MORE ACTION IS REQUIRED.

author: @teeg3030
text: I work in data analysis already, which I learned on the job!!! My major was actually in Systems Analysis,  which is closer to Computer Science. I've done the first three courses and found them very easy to follow. I wish there were more labs to practice and create our portfolio while doing so. I decided to take this certificate in order to spruce my resume, along with a Python training that I'm doing. I found the SQL coding that they're teaching up to now extremely basic, but it may be adequate for a beginner.

author: @lanadang7546
text: Nice content. Overall, I feel that this program focused too heavily on quizzes and easy assignments.  For example, the last capstone project course only required me to check a box stating that I have completed the case study. I wish it would be more practical like the UX design certificate they are having, where the learners get to complete 3 portfolio projects which are helpful for them.

author: @seoulkimchi50
text: I think it's more like opening up possibilities and also where in the world you are depending on alot. I think if you apply wtihin EMEA you'd have much higher chance to get a full-time job and esp if you apply as Junior / Internship of 3-6 months to get full time job. A lot of school in europe that teaches data-analysis also uses online platforms that teaches students then gives them chance to do internships, so the differences within 2 year program or 3 year programs are not greatly different but ofc, you have to really put efforts in making a good portfolio to showcase your skills. I'd say google analytics certificate definitely works and it opens doors but it doesn't guarantee you a job right away. Within Europe it is much more positive as many jobs looking for such roles.

author: @PD55_
text: Great video with excellent insights from real hard-working people. I've got 30 years IT consulting under my belt and you always have to be sharpening your skills, this course a great opportunity with a big ROI as Antonio mentioned. I think Wale was really spot-on at the end, if you can apply the data analytics skill to a specialized domain (a fast growing niche market), you can go "exponential" with the business opportunities out there.  Question for you Luke: I imagine there are opportunities for remote/nomad data analysts, not just corporate jobs? What do most freelance data analyst projects look like? etc. Thanks for the very practical videos, best regards.

author: @rachelwu6550
text: I felt the GDAC courses should do less talking, more real life tasks/cases/projects. E.g. video of data visualisation through Tableau public (world happiness). Sadly, it seems not many girls interested in data analysis.

author: @Major_Data
text: Really valuable content here Luke. I don't see anyone else out there doing this work.   I think people inserted some wishful thinking with regards to this cert, that it alone would be sufficient to gain employment. I don't think Google ever promised that at all.   It's great to hear these guys attest to the actual value of the course, and wonderful to hear that you have to combine it with personal branding and networking to be successful.

author: @nctarheel0619
text: One thing that's underrated about the course is the networking component. It's literally verbatim what some of these schools teach their students to do in regards to networking. Granted, it was like one week but it's what people people should pay attention to.

author: @nctarheel0619
text: Antonio is telling the truth. 2nd and 3rd course did a deep dive in Excel/Google Sheets. After the 3rd course, you literally only have learned the bare minimum in SQL. It's the 4th course that starts ramping everything up with the programming languages.

author: @julianr1760
text: I am currently taking this course and I agree that the certificate alone will not get you a job. In my opinion it is a great start for people who want to enter into this field. Not at least it gives you a view on the skills needed and also some additional knowledge that it not part of the course, to study on your own. Also noteworthy in my opinion is that there is a part about writing a resume and applying. Of course this is not the perfect interview or resume, but it grants a small view on what to expect.  And to be honest it is very big knowledge for very small price.

author: @minnami778
text: Thank you Luke.  I finished this course and Excel is heavily focused (Google Sheet). It 's very little to analysis itself which should be a star of the show. The course is focus on soft skills,¬†presentation skill, knowing the tasks and tools available as data analyst. This course does not provide much of technical skills in depth on using tools for analysis.  Is it a good course? It's one of a kind in terms of introducing you to the world of Data Analyst in a broad picture.  On positive note, I learned and understand what is data analyst, the scope of the job, what should you expected to deliver, what technical skills you need.  I am satisfied about 80%.. There is some part that go beyond my expectation; Data Visualization , course resources. But there are parts that I am quite disappointed; Analysis(If you already took the course, you will understand),  Data Manipulations , SQL, Tableau, very few practical useful labs.  Conclusion: If I would had to choose again, would I take this course ?  Yes, I would. Is this course suitable for everyone who interested in Data field with zero knowledge? Yes, it is.
